# Error & Debugging

<!-- /MarkdownTOC -->

<a id="pengetahuan-dasar"></a>

## Basic Knowledge

Rakit comes with a fairly clever debugger, where it can determine when it should
displays errors and exceptions.

This done by guessing your application environment based on server's IP address.
If you are on a local IP, the debugger will display the stack traces of the error in your application.

Conversely, if you are not on a local IP, only 500-error page (internal server error) will be displayed.
The error will be logged into the `storage/logs/` folder or sent to your email.
You can also adjust it as needed.

The 500-error page that appears, comes from the `application/views/error/500.php` file.
You can change the appearance to suit your needs.

<a id="debug-bar"></a>

## Debug Bar

The Debug Bar is a floating panel that appears in the lower right corner of your screen. this panel
contains some information about your application such as page load time,
server configuration, list of executed sql queries and the contents of the variables you dump
using the [bd()](/docs/en/helpers#bd) helper.

<figure>
    <img class="is-centered" src="data:image/png;base64," alt="debug bar">
</figure>

<a id="error--exception"></a>

## Error & Exception

Of course, you know how PHP reports errors:

```php
Parse error:  syntax error, unexpected '}' in foo.php on line 22
```

```ini
Notice: Undefined variable: foo in /bar/baz/index.php on line 9
PHP Fatal error: Uncaught Error: Call to a member function lolcat() on null in /bar/baz/qux.php:9
Stack trace:
#0 {main}
thrown in /bar/baz/qux.php on line 9

Fatal error: Uncaught Error: Call to a member function lolcat() on null in /bar/baz/qux.php:9
Stack trace:
#0 {main}
thrown in /bar/baz/qux.php on line 9
```

Of course, it's not an easy thing to track error output like this. With debugger,
errors and exceptions are displayed in a more human way, readable and much more detailed:

<figure>
    <img src=" data:image/png;base64," alt="debugger">
</figure>

That way, error messages are easier to track and handle. Error line in your source code
also highlighted. A clear message is also displayed in the section headers for you. Quite helpful right?

One more thing, Fatal errors are also caught and displayed in the same way.

<a id="konfigurasi"></a>

## Configuration

Of course it is possible to change the debugger configuration according to your needs.
To do this, you can edit the configuration values in the `application/config/debugger.php` file.

<a id="logging"></a>

## Logging

Sometimes, you may want to use the `Log` class for debugging, or just to
record some messages. Here's how to use it:

#### Write messages to logs:

:

```php
Log::write('error', 'Email ke budi gagal dikirim!');

Log::write('info', 'Email ke andi berhasil dikirim!');
```

#### Using the magic method to determine the log type:

```php
Log::info('Email ke intan berhasil dikirim!');
```

#### Passing data into log messages:

:

```php
$user = User::find(1);

Log::write('info', 'User data: ', $user);
// or,
Log::info('User data: ', $user);
```
